ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk2:0.2_0: The monks’ rules and their analysis
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk2:0.4_0: The sub-chapter on evenly all around
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk2:0.5_0: The second training rule on evenly all around,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk2:1.1_0: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk2:1.2_0: At that time the monks from the group of six wore their upper robes hanging down in front and behind. ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk2:1.3.1_0: “‘I will make rounded mouthfuls,’ this is how you should train.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk2:1.4_0: One should wear one’s upper robe evenly all around, making both corners even.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk2:1.5_0: If a monk, out of disrespect, wears his upper robe hanging down in front or behind, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk2:1.11_0: They burn in times of trouble,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk2:1.14_0: The second rule, the second training rule on fire, is finished.
